awd_titl_txt: Establishing a learning network to connect museums, scientists and rural communities to discuss scientific information to inform transdisciplinary problem-solving.
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches and resources for use in a variety of settings. This collaborative project will facilitate rural community education on climate impacts. The Carnegie Natural History Museum and the University of Pittsburgh will work together to form a network of interested community members in Mercer County and Powdermill Nature Reserve in western Pennsylvania to explore the impacts of climate and how its effect could be mitigated or accommodated. The project is has three related ideas: (1) museums hold valuable resources for understanding environmental change, (2) museums are not serving rural audiences well, and (3) complex socio-scientific environmental topics are deeply connected to social decision making in rural communities. This project will bring an inclusive approach to the discussion of socio-scientific issues in rural Western PA, through building relationships between local public audiences, STEM professionals, and informal learning specialists, creating opportunities for co-development of resources and building organizational capacity. The overarching goals of the project are to explore how museums can better serve rural stakeholders and increase the capacity for science-based conversations about human-caused climate impacts.

This project involves a cross-disciplinary team with Carnegie Museum of Natural History providing expertise in interpretation and ecological science, the University of Pittsburgh Center for Learning in Out of School Environments (UPCLOSE) providing expertise in learning research, and rural Hubs centered at Powdermill Nature Reserve (PNR) and the Mercer County Conservation District providing expertise in environmental education, conservation, and engagement with rural communities. The Hubs will coordinate professional development workshops, collaborative design sessions, and community gatherings to bring local stakeholders together to examine and adapt existing resources, including environmental science data and climate education tools, to local issues. These activities will be structured through a Research Practice Partnership. Each will have its own unique mix of geography, demographics, resources, and challenges.

The Research questions are: 1. How can the project effectively support the creation of socially safe spaces for rural Western PA communities to have science-based discussions around climate impacts? 2. How does work with rural partners influence the development of the museum's Center for Climate Studies and its mission to offer programs designed to support public engagement?
3. In what ways have museums been able to support learning about climate topics in rural communities? Data will be gathered from interviews and case studies. There will be two longitudinal studies of local network change and museum change.  A survey will also be done to assess the impact of the project on the public. Protocols will be developed in collaboration with the Hubs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Led by a conservation district in partnership with a regional museum and university researchers, the Climate and Rural Systems Partnership (CRSP) project invited community organizations to create a climate change education network. The network sought to co-develop strategies to support conversations about climate change in local settings. CRSP emerged in response to the finding that Americans’ concern about climate change is not correlated with their opportunity to, or comfort in, talking about climate change. According to Yale Climate Opinion Maps, while 64% of Americans are concerned about climate change, only 28% report talking about it, even occasionally, and in many rural communities that split is even larger. This project is designed to break down the silence beginning with a regional network to create a community of interest and support to discuss climate change.

Mindful of a long history of urban institutions bringing a deficit approach to rural education, we have approached climate change education from the perspective of local issues and personal and community relevance. We undertook three activities to develop our urban/rural partnership: the formation of a network of local actors; joint consideration of the findings of a broad county survey about climate beliefs; and showing up together, as a network, at a county fair to have climate conversations with the general public.

Seeing rural audiences in terms of the knowledge, passion, and resources they bring and opportunities they represent–as opposed to demographic and political obstacles–was a better starting point for building relationships. We acknowledged but then moved past the initial fear and social risk involved in climate conversations by focusing instead on things we can do collectively and action at any level that can help to bring people into the conversation. We found resources in rural communities, people who are following the debate, people have ideas about where the problems lie, and people who expressed curiosity to learn more. But it took time to access those resources and work together to identify and engage in shared practice.

On the museum side, staff realized that this open-ended moment was an important first step in decentering expertise–one does not have to go into an educational setting as the expert focused on persuasion, but that one can (and needs) to learn how to listen and respond to what is said. On the network side, when rural facilitators saw people they knew (and whose political affiliation they knew) engage with climate change. It was surprising that people were willing to participate in the activity and talk about their reasoning with others. Getting practice starting the conversation, alongside others, was emboldening as one facilitator who balked initially at the words “climate change” on the sign began running out to greet people who had passed by the voting booth asking if they would like to chat about climate change. As much as we know from our local experts and surveys, this real-life experience with a range of rural visitors to a county fair felt like a real test, encouraging the facilitator's interest, confidence and commitment to continue to take the risk to start these potentially tricky climate conversations.

We then conducted design studies to develop boundary objects that supported equitable climate conversations at community events. We used an iterative process that began with listening and learning about the rural residents while forming a network where rural professionals, hobbyists, and advocates collaborated with urban education and science professionals. Along the way we tried out a range of materials and facilitation approaches before settling on climate cards. Cards were rooted in local knowledge and concern, they provided just enough information to suggest a topic without introducing heavy-handed prescriptions, and, by sorting through different cards with different topics, cards provided choice to customize learning experiences for different interests, lived experiences, and values. 

Importantly, cards are also easy to make and easy to use. We wanted tools that could be used, changed, and shared without the need for extensive training. Cards are boundary objects that can be understood and engaged with from multiple points of view. We never wanted them to appear finished, polished, or slick. They are friendly points of entry that encouraged revision and reuse – a tool that, as it traveled beyond Mercer county, would always point people back to what was local, relevant, and inspiring. Our work has convinced us that the most successful climate conversations are local, relevant, and respectful. Our networked approach was key to building a community of rural collaborators who developed shared questions and practice, and who, ultimately, will be the champions who keep climate conversations going in their community. As one of the rural partners said, change requires trust and trust requires engagement: “We wanted to approach this not like a salesman but as someone who is interested in what you want to talk about.”
